CatDescriptText: Mr. Henry Robinson, parking lot attendant, Schenley Heights and Mr. Ross Hopkins, postal worker, Homewood, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, March 4, 1961, pg. 7 with question "Who do you think is largely responsible for Negro topflight entertainers being denied the chance to headline the Grade A television shows--the sponsors, the advertising agencies, or the general public?" Mr. Robinson's answer reads: "I think it is the sponsors.  I think that they think there's too much money involved and they are afraid Negroes are going to get too much of it and get somewhere."  Mr. Hopkins answer reads: "I feel obviously that it is the general public.  The sponsors hire the entertainer on the strength of the public's voice as to whether or not the entertainer will draw..."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Henry Robinson wearing beret and wool jacket, standing in front of brick wall; Portrait of Ross Hopkins wearing moustache and light colored jacket, standing on Liberty Avenue with Palace sign in background, Downtown
